Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Explore the impacts of global climate change.

column3: The combined land-surface air and sea-surface water temperature anomaly is given as the deviation from the 1951–1980 mean.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Global warming: monthly sea surface temperature anomaly
column3: This is measured at a nominal depth of 20cm, and given relative to the average temperature from the period of 1961 - 1990.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Global warming: heat content in the top 700 meters of the world's oceans
column3: Ocean heat content is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference. It is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, 10²² joules are equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.
column15: Heat content is shown for four sources: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO); Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP); National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA); and Meteorological Research Institute (MRI).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Global warming: heat content in the top 2,000 meters of the world's oceans
column3: Ocean heat content is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference. It is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, 10²² joules are equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.
column15: Heat content is shown for four sources: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO); Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP); National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA); and Meteorological Research Institute (MRI).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Mean seawater pH is shown based on in-situ measurements of pH from the Aloha station in Hawaii.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Global mean sea level rise is measured relative to the 1993 - 2008 average sea level. This is shown as three series: the widely-cited Church & White dataset; the University of Hawaii Sea Level Center (UHLSC); and the average of the two.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Climate change: Arctic minimum sea ice extent
column3: Shown is Arctic sea ice measured in September, when it reaches its minimum each year.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Climate change: Antarctic minimum sea ice extent
column3: The minimum and maximum sea ice extent typically occur in February and September each year.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Climate change: change in mass of ice sheets
column3: Cumulative change in mass of ice sheets, measured relative to a base year of 2002. For reference, 1 trillion metric tons is equal to about 260 cubic miles of ice—enough to raise sea level by about 3 millimeters.
column15: Combined measurements are based on more than 20 different studies that have been combined for each region.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

Climate Change Impacts Data Explorer: Climate change: change of mass of US glaciers
column3: Cumulative mass balance of U.S. reference glaciers, relative to the base year 1965. This is given in meters of water equivalent, which represent changes in the average thickness of a glacier.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: This metric measures the average area covered by snow, averaged over an entire year based on an analysis of weekly maps. These data cover all of North America (not including Greenland).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂) concentration is measured in parts per million (ppm).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Atmospheric methane (CH₄) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Atmospheric nitrous oxide (N₂O) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂) concentration is measured in parts per million (ppm). Long-term trends in CO₂ concentrations can be measured at high-resolution using preserved air samples from ice cores.
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Atmospheric methane (CH₄) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column3: Atmospheric nitrous oxide (N₂O) concentration is measured in parts per billion (ppb).
column17: Data explorer: how is the Earth's climate changing?

column10: NSIDC (National Snow and Ice Data Center) via the US EPA
column15: Original data on Antarctic Sea Ice comes from the NSIDC (National Snow and Ice Data Center). Sea ice data and image archive: https://nsidc.org/data/seaice_index/archive

column10: NSIDC (National Snow and Ice Data Center) via the US EPA
column15: Original data on Antarctic Sea Ice comes from the NSIDC (National Snow and Ice Data Center). Sea ice data and image archive: https://nsidc.org/data/seaice_index/archive

The original data series is published from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).

CSIRO (Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation). 2016 update to data originally published in: Domingues, C.M., J.A. Church, N.J. White, P.J. Gleckler, S.E. Wijffels, P.M. Barker, and J.R. Dunn. 2008. Improved estimates of upper-ocean warming and multi-decadal sea-level rise. Nature 453:1090–1094. www.cmar.csiro.au/sealevel/thermal_expansion_ocean_heat_timeseries.html

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.

The original data series is published from the Institute of Atmopsheric Physics (IAP).

IAP (Institute of Atmospheric Physics). 2021 update to data originally published in: Cheng, L., K.E. Trenberth, J. Fasullo, T. Boyer, J. Abraham, and J. Zhu. 2017. Improved estimates of ocean heat content from 1960 to 2015. Science Advances 3(3):e1601545.

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.

The original data series is published from the Meteorological Research Institute/Japan Meteorological Agency.

MRI/JMA (Meteorological Research Institute/Japan Meteorological Agency). 2021. Global ocean heat content. www.data.jma.go.jp/gmd/kaiyou/english/ohc/ohc_global_en.html

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.

The original data series is published from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA). Global ocean heat and salt content. www.nodc.noaa.gov/OC5/3M_HEAT_CONTENT.

Ocean heat content is measured in 10²² joules. For reference, one 10²² joules is equal to approximately 17 times the amount of energy used globally every year.

It is measured relative to the 1971–2000 average, which is set at zero for reference.

column15: This series measures sea level rise from the Church and White (2011)'s reconstruction of 20th century sea level rise (https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2005GL024826). The values are shown as change in sea level in millimeters compared to the 1993-2008 average.

This series measures sea level rise from the University of Hawaii's Sea Level Center Fast Track (http://uhslc.soest.hawaii.edu/data/?fd). The values are shown as change in sea level in millimeters compared to the 1993-2008 average.

This series measures the average sea level rise from two sources:

1. the University of Hawaii's Sea Level Center Fast Track (http://uhslc.soest.hawaii.edu/data/?fd).

2. Church and White (2011)'s historical reconstruction (https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2005GL024826).

The values are shown as change in sea level in millimeters compared to the 1993-2008 average.
